abstract: The blending weights between the FK demand and the your target per demand type.

declaration.code: var animationOverrideWeight: (position: Float, rotation: Float) { get set }

overview:
## Discussion

Each demand uses either the value you set using [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/target] and [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/lookAtTargetPosition], or computes one from the FK demand pose. These weights control the blending between the two.

The values are in the closed range `[0, 1]`, where a weight value of `0` means the constraint demands are computed from the FK demand, and a weight value of `1` means that [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/target] is used. All values in-between represent linear blend of the two. Default values are 0.

# animationOverrideWeight

**Instance Property**

The blending weights between the FK demand and the your target per demand type.

## Declaration

```swift
var animationOverrideWeight: (position: Float, rotation: Float) { get set }
```

## Discussion

Each demand uses either the value you set using [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/target] and [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/lookAtTargetPosition], or computes one from the FK demand pose. These weights control the blending between the two.

The values are in the closed range `[0, 1]`, where a weight value of `0` means the constraint demands are computed from the FK demand, and a weight value of `1` means that [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/IKComponent/Constraint/target] is used. All values in-between represent linear blend of the two. Default values are 0.
title: animationOverrideWeight
